captions.text:
Developers, blink twice if the post-apocalypse
is forcing you to make games about it against
your will.

I mean, there has to be some explanation for
why we seem to be constantly banging this

extremely sweaty drum, and I doubt it&#39;s because
there are still post-apocalypse stories that
desperately need to be told.

Help me out here, Bethesda, why does Rage
2 have to exist?

Actually, before you answer that, remind me:
why did Rage 1 have to exist?

&#39;Cos all Rage 1 was in retrospect was a rather
unmemorable little sidetrack that meant we
couldn&#39;t have Doom 2016 for another few years.

Like an extremely long queue outside a cake
and blowjob shop.

So Rage 1 was a puddingy fart in an overcrowded
swimming pool and Bethesda must have said
to Id &quot;Alright, fine, just make Doom.&quot;

So they made Doom and it kicked arse and then
they were like &quot;Great, we&#39;ve figured it out.
NOW let&#39;s make another Rage.&quot;
Why?
Why are we still bothering with Rage?
And why do you have a black eye?
&quot;I walked into a door!

I mean, because it&#39;s a post-apocalypse story
that desperately needs to be told, that&#39;s
why.

Now let&#39;s make Rage 2 and they&#39;re definitely
not making me say this.&quot;
Well, let&#39;s give Rage 2 a chance.

I mean, there might be a few things that a
shooty drivey post-apocalypse sandbox can

do with the colour magenta that Far Cry New
Dawn didn&#39;t already do this year.

In Rage 2, you&#39;re a Ranger at a Ranger summer
camp or something who is one of the few survivors
when the Authority attack.

You remember the Authority, they were the
main villains in Rage 1 that the game eventually

got around to introducing after a not inconsiderable
amount of fannying about.

So you have to take the fight to them just
as soon as you&#39;ve met your own fannying about
quota.

The influence from Doom 2016 is obvious because
the combat has an emphasis on fast-paced double

jumping around and upon death most enemies
will vomit up the last few Mars bars they

ate to keep your health ticking over, but
as is so often the case when something that

works well for a linear shooter is put in
an open world sandbox setting, Rage 2 has
an issue with pacing.

In the same way that I have an issue with
my uncomfortably large twelve inch knob, because
Rage 2 doesn&#39;t have any fucking pacing.

You start the game and the entire sandbox
map is available from the word go.

Granted our character is someone who is familiar
with the world, and has presumably been through

all these places already when the ranger camp
needed groceries and printer toner, but I

never get a sense that the world is unfolding
as we play, or that the game&#39;s scope is increasing
or that we&#39;re growing into the space.

All the space just gets thrown at me at once
like a wet poppadom to the mush.

I mean, the first vehicle you get is the best
one in the game, it&#39;s got a mounted minigun

so you can clear out half of most bandit camps
before you&#39;ve even set foot in the place like
a psychotically determined Jehovah&#39;s Witness.

And then you unlock a flying vehicle with
precisely zero ceremony that you can infinitely

spawn for roughly the cost of a Cornish pasty
and chips apiece.

And after you&#39;ve got that, ascended to maximum
height and gone &quot;Yep, that&#39;s a sandbox map

alright,&quot; then all of that space in the sandbox
map ceases to be an exciting land to explore

where danger and adventure might lurk around
every corner but a series of indistinct smeary

blurs that speed by as we zoom uncontested
from one clearly marked objective to the next.

Things liven up when you do get into combat,
so I&#39;d take on bandit camps mainly just to
keep myself amused.

And is that really the attitude you want me
to take?

Combat being something I do not out of necessity
or for challenge or self-improvement but for

the same reason I keep turning my dog upside
down, &#39;cos I find his futile attempts to bite
my hands off hilarious?

There are a bunch of different weapons to
look for but I&#39;d say you can officially stop

looking once you&#39;ve got the Shotgun, Rifle
and Rocket Launcher.

There&#39;re some gimmick weapons, like the pistol
whose bullets burst into flames when you snap

your fingers or the gravity gun that flings
your targets towards a second target like

the instant yo-yo gun from Red Faction Armageddon,
but I think &quot;press the button and the thing

dies&quot; is a model of efficiency that works
pretty well for guns, whereas &quot;press the button

then press another button to turn the bullet
on&quot; sounds like a gun developed by whoever

designed the current American healthcare system,
and I barely used them, always swiftly returning

to the prestigious law firm of Shotgun, Rifle
and Rocket Launcher.

Early in the game, when I still felt remotely
challenged by the combat, I thought the pace

issue was that after you&#39;ve cleared out a
bandit camp like a nitrous-fueled Roomba,

built up a ninety-seven kill combo and made
all your HUD elements flash like a pinball

machine in a rave, after everyone&#39;s dead the
game goes &quot;Whoops, this camp isn&#39;t finished

yet, you haven&#39;t found all three hidden prize
boxes&quot; and then the pace would audibly screech

to a halt as I went back and forth across
the empty camp looking for the Christmas tree.

Occasionally fruitlessly swinging my rifle
butt at the empty air directly above one of

the ammo crates &#39;cos they&#39;re only just tall
enough for you to melee without crouching

as long as you tuck it between your testicles
first.

But as the game went on, I began to ask myself,
what do I expect to find in those prize boxes?

&#39;Cos unless they&#39;re stashing a properly structured
plot and a general purpose in life in one
of those, probably safe to leave it.

It&#39;ll either be upgrade tokens or money for
buying upgrade tokens, and I have so many

bloody weapons and abilities to upgrade beyond
a certain point it&#39;s just another squirt of
piss in an industrial piss milking facility.

Thanks partly to the increasingly popular
shitty interface, I was all the way through

to post-ending fuckabouts and industriously
fucking about before I discovered that it

was possible to upgrade your superpowers,
which illustrates how necessary the upgrades
are.

You&#39;ve got your super punch, your super stomp,
your super dash, your super run that&#39;s faster

than the normal run but not quite as fast
as the super dash and which I used less often
than the fucking quit button.

Then there&#39;s your health upgrades and your
weapon upgrades and your gregade upnades and

your vehicle upgrades - that&#39;s a laugh, like
I give a shit if my between-fights commute

mobile can go vroom more than it previously
went vroom.

If you want to focus on building the player
character&#39;s strength and ability to do stuff,

fine, but it needs a suitable game world for
that player to do stuff in, it needs a Breath

of the Wild, something expansive and beautiful
and hostile that takes more than four or five
travel sweets to get across.

Ideally one where the GPS navigator has the
ability to warn you that a turn&#39;s coming up

more than ten feet before you get to the fucking
thing.

By the end of Rage 2, I didn&#39;t feel like anything
had truly threatened me.

The main baddy shoots up my summer camp at
the start and then proceeds to sit on his

underground cybertoilet rubbing his hands
inglee while I go to three old farts who say

&quot;Oh yeah, we totally knew the main baddy would
come back and we&#39;ve got a plan to kill him

all set up already and all you need to do
is fill out the shopping list.&quot;

Seven or eight short missions later the plan
goes off without a hitch and we utterly chump

Mr. Bigmouth Scarytrousers &#39;cos he got inside
a giant pile of spam whose unbeatable strategy

was to slowly bring its fists down on the
spot where I was three seconds ago and then

pause for eight or nine minutes to get its
breath back.
Rage?
I&#39;ve been more enraged by my own trousers.

But that&#39;s uncomfortably large 12-inch knobs
for you.
